text.content: Im gonna do the review the book and the movie as a whole. Like i said, i had already watched the movie a long time ago but still not remember anything quite significant to plot. however, when i read the book, it was all comming back to my mind and it kept me guessing what comming up next. the author/director of the book and the movie said the book is complementary to the movie and vice versa and i think this is absolutely the truth in this case. both of the movie and book are very faithful to each other, i could say they are identical but execute in different takes. we watch the movie in the third person perspective but in the the book we get to see the first person point of view from both Mitsuha and Taki. this really helps enhancing the experience of the audience like me. not only I get to see how both of this main characters feelings and thoughts to the surrounding environment but also see some of the questions i made when reading being answered when i watch.

text.content: One thing i notice after watching this movie is the similarity between this one and the movie Woodjob. both of the movies show how Japanese people look at and value their culture and tradition. doing so, they are raising awareness for the young generation to step up and and take responsibility to preserve the culture. we saw how Taki and Yuki, both are clueless city boys live their best lives in remote area, learning the to value and respect culture that will remain hidden forever to them if they never actually be there. both movies did a really good job at showing and explaining the why people from old generation worship and faithful to their traditions, and also introducing the myth, religious  customs, holy spirits and gods. on the other hand though, we saw how desperate Mitsuha is when she find herself stuck in this remote and quiet village with lacking of fancy restaurants and cafes, she dreams of breaking free and living in a big city Tokyo with fast-paced life style and probably never getting bored or running out of things to do. However, underneath all of that, we sympathize the loneliness she is living in Itomori, with 2 best friends and small family and the absent of the both mom and dad. she took the responsible of entire family and village since the very young age. the worst part of it is always being look at with the judging eyes from her peers.
